channel.title: Comments on: Catching the OUTPUT of your DML statements
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: And a plug for my post on using it in conjunction with the MERGE statement :) <a href="/index.php/DataMgmt/DBProgramming/MSSQLServer/using-t-sql-output-and-merge">Using T-SQL OUTPUT and MERGE To Link Old and New Keys</a>
item.content:encoded: And a plug for my post on using it in conjunction with the MERGE statement ðŸ™‚ Using T-SQL OUTPUT and MERGE To Link Old and New Keys

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: The OUTPUT statement is very powerful and solves a bunch of problems that you had to do with temp tables prior to the output statement. See also my post here: <a href="/index.php/DataMgmt/DataDesign/sql-advent-2011-day-11">SQL Advent 2011 Day 11: DML statements with the OUTPUT clause</a> it also shows how to output into a variable
item.content:encoded: The OUTPUT statement is very powerful and solves a bunch of problems that you had to do with temp tables prior to the output statement. See also my post here: SQL Advent 2011 Day 11: DML statements with the OUTPUT clause it also shows how to output into a variable
